title: Dynamical Systems and Active Inference
description: Mathematical treatment of dynamical systems theory and its application to Active Inference modeling.
learning_objectives: Understand dynamical systems in Active Inference
Apply to neural and cognitive systems

content.overview: Dynamical systems theory provides the mathematical foundation for understanding how Active Inference systems evolve over time. It describes the behavior of complex systems, their stability properties, and how they respond to perturbations.

continuous_dynamical_systems.autonomous_systems: dx/dt = f(x) - evolution depends only on current state, no explicit time dependence
continuous_dynamical_systems.non_autonomous_systems: dx/dt = f(x,t) - time-varying dynamics with external forcing or parameter changes
continuous_dynamical_systems.equilibrium_points: Fixed points x* where f(x*) = 0, representing stationary states of the system
continuous_dynamical_systems.phase_portrait: Geometric representation of system trajectories in state space, showing flow and equilibria
continuous_dynamical_systems.stability: Linear stability analysis using Jacobian matrix J = ∂f/∂x evaluated at equilibrium
continuous_dynamical_systems.manifolds: Invariant sets that trajectories cannot cross, including stable/unstable manifolds
continuous_dynamical_systems.ergodicity: Long-term time averages equal ensemble averages over invariant measures
continuous_dynamical_systems.structural_stability: Robustness of qualitative behavior under small perturbations of f

stability_theory.linear_systems: For dx/dt = Ax, stability determined by eigenvalues: Re(λ) < 0 for asymptotic stability
stability_theory.lyapunov_stability: Equilibrium x* is Lyapunov stable if ∀ε>0, ∃δ>0 such that ||x(0)-x*|| < δ ⇒ ||x(t)-x*|| < ε ∀t ≥ 0
stability_theory.asymptotic_stability: Lyapunov stable and attracting: solutions converge to equilibrium as t → ∞
stability_theory.exponential_stability: Convergence at exponential rate: ||x(t)-x*|| ≤ K e^{-αt} ||x(0)-x*||
stability_theory.global_stability: Asymptotic stability for all initial conditions in the domain
stability_theory.lyapunov_functions: V(x) such that V̇(x) ≤ 0 with equality only at equilibrium, proving stability
stability_theory.input_to_state_stability: Stability under bounded inputs, generalization of Lyapunov stability
stability_theory.structural_stability: Qualitative behavior unchanged under small perturbations

bifurcation_theory.saddle_node_bifurcation: At μ = μ_c, two equilibria (stable + saddle) collide and disappear as μ crosses μ_c
bifurcation_theory.transcritical_bifurcation: Two equilibria exchange stability at μ = μ_c, common in population dynamics
bifurcation_theory.pitchfork_bifurcation: Symmetric bifurcation where stable equilibrium splits into three (two stable, one unstable)
bifurcation_theory.hopf_bifurcation: Supercritical: stable equilibrium becomes unstable, giving rise to stable limit cycle
bifurcation_theory.subcritical_hopf: Unstable limit cycle appears before equilibrium destabilizes
bifurcation_theory.period_doubling: Limit cycle loses stability, replaced by cycle of double period; cascades to chaos
bifurcation_theory.homoclinic_bifurcation: Homoclinic orbit to saddle point appears/disappears, often signals global changes
bifurcation_theory.normal_forms: Simplified equations capturing essential bifurcation dynamics near criticality

attractor_landscape.fixed_points: Stable equilibria where trajectories converge; characterized by eigenvalues with negative real parts
attractor_landscape.limit_cycles: Closed periodic orbits that attract nearby trajectories; characterized by Floquet multipliers
attractor_landscape.torus_attractors: Quasiperiodic motion on 2D tori; characterized by incommensurate frequencies
attractor_landscape.strange_attractors: Fractal sets with sensitive dependence on initial conditions; positive Lyapunov exponents
attractor_landscape.basins_of_attraction: Sets of initial conditions converging to specific attractor; fractal boundaries possible
attractor_landscape.bifurcations_in_attractor_landscape: How attractor structure changes with parameters
attractor_landscape.multistability: Coexistence of multiple attractors with different basins
attractor_landscape.transient_chaos: Chaotic behavior before convergence to regular attractor

examples.name: Lotka-Volterra Predator-Prey Model
examples.description: Classic ecological model showing oscillatory behavior and stability analysis
examples.problem: Model predator-prey dynamics: dx/dt = αx - βxy, dy/dt = δxy - γy
examples.equilibrium_analysis: Equilibrium at (γ/δ, α/β); Jacobian eigenvalues determine stability
examples.phase_portrait: Closed orbits around equilibrium showing periodic predator-prey cycles
examples.bifurcation_analysis: As parameters change, equilibrium can become unstable leading to limit cycles
examples.active_inference_connection: Models belief updating where predator represents uncertainty and prey represents information

examples.name: Neural Wilson-Cowan Equations
examples.description: Neural mass model capturing cortical dynamics and phase transitions
examples.equations: dE/dt = -E + S(μ_E + w_EE E - w_EI I + P_E), dI/dt = -I + S(μ_I + w_IE E - w_II I + P_I)
examples.bifurcations: Hopf bifurcation from stable equilibrium to limit cycle oscillations
examples.active_inference_relevance: Represents predictive coding dynamics where oscillations encode prediction errors
examples.experimental_validation: Matches EEG/MEG data showing gamma oscillations during perception

examples.name: Belief Propagation on Factor Graphs
examples.description: Message passing as dynamical system converging to marginal posteriors
examples.problem: Solve inference in graphical models using iterative message updates
examples.dynamical_formulation: Message updates as gradient flow on free energy landscape
examples.convergence_analysis: Fixed points correspond to exact marginals for tree-structured graphs
examples.loopy_belief_propagation: Approximate solution for graphs with cycles using damped updates
examples.active_inference_application: Neural message passing implements hierarchical belief updating

examples.name: Hopfield Network Dynamics
examples.description: Attractor neural network showing associative memory as dynamical system
examples.problem: Design network that converges to stored patterns: dS_i/dt = -S_i + ∑_j J_ij tanh(S_j)
examples.attractor_landscape: Energy function E = -∑_{ij} J_ij S_i S_j with minima at stored patterns
examples.stability_analysis: Lyapunov function proves convergence to local minima
examples.capacity_analysis: Maximum patterns N ≈ 0.15n where n is network size
examples.active_inference_connection: Associative memory as generative model retrieval mechanism

examples.name: Kuramoto Oscillator Model
examples.description: Synchronization dynamics in coupled oscillator networks
examples.problem: Model synchronization: dθ_i/dt = ω_i + (K/N) ∑_j sin(θ_j - θ_i)
examples.mean_field_approximation: For large N, derive order parameter r = (1/N) |∑ e^{iθ_j}|
examples.bifurcation_analysis: Incoherent state becomes unstable above critical coupling K_c
examples.active_inference_relevance: Models consensus formation in multi-agent Active Inference systems
examples.neural_application: Explains synchronization in neural populations during binding and attention

examples.name: Lorenz Attractor
examples.description: Chaotic system showing sensitive dependence and strange attractor
examples.equations: dx/dt = σ(y-x), dy/dt = x(ρ-z)-y, dz/dt = xy-βz
examples.parameter_values: Classic chaotic regime: σ=10, ρ=28, β=8/3
examples.active_inference_interpretation: Chaotic dynamics as model of complex belief trajectories in high-dimensional inference

stochastic_dynamical_systems.langevin_equation: dx = f(x)dt + σ(x,t) dW_t - stochastic differential equation with drift and diffusion
stochastic_dynamical_systems.ito_vs_stratonovich: Ito: ∫ σ dW uses left endpoints; Stratonovich: symmetric interpretation for physical systems
stochastic_dynamical_systems.fokker_planck_equation: ∂_t p = -∇ · (μ p) + (1/2) ∇ · ∇ · (D p) where μ is drift, D is diffusion matrix
stochastic_dynamical_systems.stationary_distribution: Solution to 0 = -∇ · (μ p) + (1/2) ∇ · ∇ · (D p); often π(x) ∝ exp(-∫ 2μ/D dx)
stochastic_dynamical_systems.fluctuation_dissipation: Diffusion matrix D relates to friction γ: D = kT/γ (Einstein relation)
stochastic_dynamical_systems.first_passage_times: Distribution of times to reach absorbing boundary; solved using backward Kolmogorov equation
stochastic_dynamical_systems.large_deviations: Probability of rare events scales as exp(-I/ε) where I is rate function
stochastic_dynamical_systems.stochastic_resonance: Noise can enhance signal detection in nonlinear systems
stochastic_dynamical_systems.active_inference_stochastic_dynamics: Neural variability as beneficial noise enabling exploration and adaptation

chaos_and_complexity.sensitive_dependence: ||x(t) - x₀(t)|| ≈ ||δx(0)|| e^{λ₁ t} where λ₁ > 0 indicates chaos
chaos_and_complexity.lyapunov_exponent_spectrum: Ordered exponents λ₁ ≥ λ₂ ≥ ... characterize expansion/contraction rates
chaos_and_complexity.fractal_dimensions: Capacity dimension D_C, Information dimension D_I, Correlation dimension D_C for strange attractors
chaos_and_complexity.predictability_horizon: τ ≈ (1/λ₁) ln(δ/ε) where δ is initial uncertainty, ε is prediction tolerance
chaos_and_complexity.period_doubling_route: Feigenbaum cascade: period doubles accumulate at r_∞ with universal scaling
chaos_and_complexity.strange_attractor_properties: Dense periodic orbits, ergodic invariant measure, sensitive dependence
chaos_and_complexity.complexity_measures: Kolmogorov complexity, Lempel-Ziv complexity, fractal dimensions
chaos_and_complexity.edge_of_chaos: Critical parameter values where systems balance order and disorder optimally
chaos_and_complexity.active_inference_chaos: Chaotic dynamics enable flexible inference in complex, changing environments

control_of_dynamical_systems.controllability: Rank of controllability matrix C = [B, AB, ..., A^{n-1}B] = n for full controllability
control_of_dynamical_systems.observability: Rank of observability matrix O = [C^T, (CA)^T, ..., (CA^{n-1})^T] = n for full observability
control_of_dynamical_systems.stabilizability: Controllable subspace can be stabilized using state feedback u = -Kx
control_of_dynamical_systems.detectability: Observable subspace can be detected using state estimation
control_of_dynamical_systems.linear_quadratic_regulator: u = -Kx minimizes J = ∫ (x^T Q x + u^T R u) dt with Riccati equation
control_of_dynamical_systems.adaptive_control: Controller parameters updated online to handle changing system dynamics
control_of_dynamical_systems.model_predictive_control: Optimize control sequence over prediction horizon, implement first step
control_of_dynamical_systems.active_inference_control: Expected free energy minimization provides optimal control policy

connections_to_active_inference.brain_dynamics: Neural population activity evolves as high-dimensional dynamical system with attractors representing beliefs
connections_to_active_inference.belief_dynamics: Variational inference implements gradient flow on free energy landscape: dμ/dt = -∇_μ F(μ)
connections_to_active_inference.policy_dynamics: Expected free energy minimization defines policy evolution: dπ/dt = -∇_π G(π)
connections_to_active_inference.learning_dynamics: Synaptic plasticity follows dynamical equations: dW/dt = -∇_W F(W,x) + η(t)
connections_to_active_inference.hierarchical_inference: Multi-level belief propagation as coupled dynamical systems across cortical hierarchy
connections_to_active_inference.attention_mechanisms: Precision weighting modulates effective dynamics, changing attractor landscape
connections_to_active_inference.exploration_exploitation: Stochastic dynamics enable exploration of belief space, deterministic convergence for exploitation
connections_to_active_inference.phase_transitions: Critical phenomena in neural dynamics correspond to bifurcations in inference regimes
connections_to_active_inference.predictive_coding: Hierarchical message passing as dynamical system converging to predictive equilibrium

numerical_methods.integration_schemes: Explicit Euler (simple but unstable), Runge-Kutta 4th order (accurate), implicit methods (stable for stiff systems)
numerical_methods.stability_analysis: Region of absolute stability for integration methods; A-stability for stiff systems
numerical_methods.bifurcation_detection: Pseudo-arclength continuation, branch switching, bifurcation test functions
numerical_methods.parameter_estimation: Maximum likelihood estimation, Bayesian inference, system identification from time series
numerical_methods.lyapunov_exponent_computation: Benettin algorithm, Wolf method, Jacobian-based approaches
numerical_methods.fractal_dimension_estimation: Box counting, generalized entropy, correlation sum methods
numerical_methods.continuation_methods: AUTO, MATCONT, COCO for bifurcation analysis and branch following
numerical_methods.spectral_methods: Floquet theory for periodic orbits, transfer operator for ergodic theory
numerical_methods.active_inference_numerical_methods: Variational integrators for symplectic inference dynamics

common_misconceptions.misconception: All dynamical systems are deterministic and predictable
common_misconceptions.clarification: Stochastic dynamical systems with noise are ubiquitous in nature and essential for modeling real-world phenomena
common_misconceptions.evidence: Brownian motion, thermal fluctuations, neural spiking variability all require stochastic descriptions
common_misconceptions.active_inference_implication: Stochastic dynamics enable exploration and prevent overfitting in inference

common_misconceptions.misconception: Chaos means the system behaves randomly or unpredictably
common_misconceptions.clarification: Chaotic systems are completely deterministic but extremely sensitive to initial conditions, making long-term prediction impossible
common_misconceptions.evidence: The logistic map x_{n+1} = 4x_n(1-x_n) shows period-doubling route to chaos with positive Lyapunov exponent

common_misconceptions.misconception: Stable systems have simple, unchanging behavior
common_misconceptions.clarification: Stable systems can exhibit complex dynamics including limit cycles, quasiperiodicity, and even chaos within stability boundaries
common_misconceptions.evidence: The Lorenz attractor is stable (trajectories don't escape) but shows chaotic dynamics with sensitive dependence
common_misconceptions.stability_definition: Stability means bounded solutions and convergence to attractors, not necessarily simple behavior

common_misconceptions.misconception: Bifurcations only occur in simple systems with few parameters
common_misconceptions.clarification: High-dimensional systems undergo bifurcations that can create complex attractor landscapes and hysteresis
common_misconceptions.evidence: Neural networks show bifurcation cascades during learning, creating multiple stable states
common_misconceptions.active_inference_relevance: Bifurcations explain sudden changes in inference regimes and decision-making

common_misconceptions.misconception: Attractors are always simple fixed points or limit cycles
common_misconceptions.clarification: Strange attractors have fractal structure and can be extremely complex with non-integer dimensions
common_misconceptions.evidence: The Lorenz attractor has dimension ≈2.06, lying between 2D and 3D manifolds
common_misconceptions.measurement: Fractal dimension quantifies the complexity and information content of attractors

common_misconceptions.misconception: Dynamical systems theory only applies to physics and engineering
common_misconceptions.clarification: Dynamical systems provide foundational framework for neuroscience, psychology, economics, and social systems
common_misconceptions.evidence: Neural dynamics, belief updating, market behavior, and social consensus all follow dynamical laws
common_misconceptions.unification: Active Inference shows how apparently diverse systems share common dynamical principles
